docs.lead_paragraph: They loaded Mcdonald Mafu into the donkey cart about 10 minutes after the doctor signed his papers. He had been dead for two days -- one less than he had lived -- but it took his mother a while to make it to the district hospital so far from her home. The whole transaction lasted about two minutes. Dr. Bart Vander Plaetse took a piece of paper with the words ''Notice of the Death of a Person'' printed on top. He wrote down the dead boy's name and for his age he scribbled a fraction: 1/52.

headline.main: Doctors Powerless as AIDS Rakes Africa

docs.abstract: First article in series Dead Zones discusses AIDS epidemic in Zimbabwe; death from every type of disease has become so common in Zimbabwe, as in much of Africa, that it no longer seems to matter that country has become center of world's AIDS epidemic; recent studies suggest that Zimbabwe may have highest AIDS infection rate on earth; savage virus has left few people untouched; it has devastated families and communities; seen through weary eyes of doctors and nurses who must attend to sick people around them, AIDS is just another word for dying, and it is just another disease; with average of $10 to spend on each person's health every year, most African countries have no money for tests, fancy drugs or complicated support networks; Zimbabwe once had health system that was envy of southern Africa, fueled by AIDS and also by increasing poverty and instability, illness has begun to overcome country; maps; photos (M)
docs.snippet: They loaded Mcdonald Mafu into the donkey cart about 10 minutes after the doctor signed his papers. He had been dead for two days -- one less than he had lived -- but it took his mother a while to make it to the district hospital so far from her...

docs.lead_paragraph: There was nothing out of the ordinary about the slender glass tubes of blood that arrived in Sharon S. Rotun's laboratory late in the afternoon of March 20, 1998. A pale, stocky woman with the impatient manner of someone who is overworked and underpaid, Rotun was the microbiology supervisor at United Hospital Medical Center, a small community hospital in the working-class town of Port Chester, N.Y., just north of Manhattan in Westchester County. The two blood cultures were among roughly a dozen sent to the lab that day. Whoever ordered the testing was evidently in a hurry, Rotun recalls, because he or she hadn't even bothered to scribble the usual instructions on the accompanying slip. The blood belonged to a 79-year-old Westchester County man, a retired New York City narcotics detective who had been admitted to the hospital earlier that day. For the past year and a half, the detective's kidneys had been failing him, a condition that required him to undergo dialysis three times a week. On most days, he tolerated the tedious procedure with a smile. But on the morning of March 20, the retired detective awoke in an unusually sour mood.
docs.abstract: Sheryl Gay Stolberg article on health threat posed by growing number of common bacteria that are becoming resistant to antibiotics; medical experts are most concerned about staphylococus strains resistant to powerful antibiotic vancomycin; drug manufacturers, who all but abandoned development of new antibiotics on theory they were no longer needed, are hustling to catch up but are at least several years away from marketing new generation of drugs; photos (L)
